senses.de: Result or effect of an action or condition.
senses.ex: Many have been laid off from work as a consequence of the administration's policies.

Tips.title: Cause and Effect
Tips.description: Use 'consequence' to discuss the result of something that happened earlier.
Tips.example: Eating too much sugar can have negative health consequences.

Tips.title: Not Always Bad
Tips.description: 'Consequence' can be neutral or positive, not just negative.
Tips.example: One consequence of diligent study is better grades.

Tips.title: Linked Actions
Tips.description: Use 'as a consequence' to clearly link the cause and its result.
Tips.example: She arrived late and as a consequence, she missed the meeting.

senses.ex: The water shortage is a matter of grave consequence.

Tips.title: Significant Matters
Tips.description: Use 'consequence' to express the level of importance something holds.
Tips.example: This research has consequences for all of us.

Tips.title: Not Always Serious
Tips.description: 'Consequence' can indicate varying degrees of importance, from trivial to crucial.
Tips.example: For tourists, a little rain is of no consequence.

Tips.title: Weighing Importance
Tips.description: 'Matter of consequence' is used when considering if something is worth attention.
Tips.example: The meeting is a matter of great consequence for the company's future.

senses.de: A punishment or negative result of a wrong action.
senses.ex: Criminal actions must have serious consequences.

Tips.title: Negative Outcome
Tips.description: 'Consequence' often refers to a bad outcome resulting from someone's actions.
Tips.example: He was caught cheating and now he has to face the consequences.

Tips.title: Resulting Responsibility
Tips.description: To 'bear the consequences' means to accept responsibility for one's actions.
Tips.example: You must bear the consequences of your mistakes.

Tips.title: Punitive Context
Tips.description: In legal or disciplinary situations, 'consequences' often mean punishment.
Tips.example: The thief understood the consequences of his crime after his arrest.

Aftermath.wordDefinition:
Both aftermath and consequence refer to events or results that occur after something else.

However, aftermath specifically refers to the immediate aftermath or results of a more significant event, whereas consequence can refer to both immediate and long-term effects of a particular action or decision.

For example, the aftermath of a natural disaster such as a hurricane would refer to the immediate aftermath, such as the destruction of buildings, homes and infrastructure.

Corollary.wordDefinition:
Both consequence and corollary refer to results or outcomes that are produced by a certain action, event or circumstance.

A corollary is a natural or logical conclusion that can be drawn from a set of premises or facts.

It is often used in a more formal or scientific context. For example, the corollary of Newton's second law of motion states that if an object is acted upon by a force, it will accelerate in the direction of that force.

In simpler terms, consequence refers to what happens as a result of a specific action or decision, while corollary refers to a conclusion that can be drawn from a set of facts or premises.

Effect.wordDefinition:
Effect also refers to a result that happens as a result of an action or decision, but it does not necessarily have a negative connotation.

It can refer to both positive and negative outcomes. For example, if you exercise every day, the effect may be that you become stronger and healthier.

Consequence implies a negative outcome, while effect can refer to both positive and negative outcomes.

Fallout.wordDefinition:
Fallout refers to the negative consequences of a specific event or action, usually related to something unexpected or unwanted.

For example, the fallout of a nuclear detonation could be harmful radiation, destruction of buildings and serious health problems.

Overall, while both words refer to outcomes of actions, consequence is a more general term used to describe any result, while fallout is more specifically used to describe negative or bad outcomes from a specific event or decision.

Outcome.wordDefinition:
Outcome refers to a result that happens as a result of a process or event, and may have either positive or negative implications.

For example, the outcome of a sports game could be a win or a loss.

Both words are used to describe results, but consequence typically refers to a negative or unwanted result, while outcome can apply to both positive and negative results.

Ramification.wordDefinition:
Ramification refers to the implications or consequences that result from a decision or action, particularly if it's complex and has many different outcomes.

It often implies a series of effects, one leading to another, that can have long-lasting impacts. For example, if a company decides to lay off workers, the ramification might be that those workers struggle to find new jobs and the local economy is negatively affected.

Consequence is typically used for a single result, and ramification is often used for complex chains of events or impacts that result from a decision or action.

Repercussion.wordDefinition:
Consequence and repercussion are both words that describe a result or outcome of something that has happened.

However, consequence generally has a more neutral connotation, simply referring to the effect or result of an action, while repercussion often implies a negative consequence or an indirect effect that can be far-reaching.

The repercussions of cheating on that same exam could be severe, such as getting caught and facing disciplinary action or damaging your reputation with teachers and classmates.

Consequence is a more general term that can apply to any outcome, while repercussion implies a more significant and often negative effect that stems from a specific action or situation.

Result.wordDefinition:
Consequence and result are both words that describe the outcome of a particular action or event.

Result is a more neutral term that can refer to any outcome, positive or negative. For example, if you study hard for a test, the result might be a good grade.

Consequence is often used to describe negative outcomes, while result is more general and can refer to any outcome.

Sequel.wordDefinition:
Sequel on the other hand, refers to something that follows or comes after something else. In the context of movies or books, a sequel is a continuation of a story or plot.

For example, the movie 'The Godfather' has a sequel called 'The Godfather: Part II', which continues the story of the first movie.

Sequels are used when there is more to the story or when there is more to be explored.

So, in summary, consequences are the negative outcomes of an action or decision, while sequels are the continuation of a story.

quotes.Text: A lot of them have families to feed, and I think it's a tragic situation where players aren't comfortable speaking what's on their mind or what's right because they're afraid of consequences that come along with it. That's not an ideal environment for anybody.
quotes.Title: American Athlete
quotes.Name: Colin Kaepernick

quotes.Text: As leakers take great risks in releasing information, assuring them that they are not sacrificing themselves in vain and that their leaks would have public consequences would most likely encourage more people to leak.
quotes.Title: Belarusian Writer
quotes.Name: Evgeny Morozov

quotes.Text: The world is not looking for servants, there are plenty of these, but for masters, men who form their purposes and then carry them out, let the consequences be what they may.
quotes.Title: American President
quotes.Name: Woodrow Wilson

quotes.Text: If they are unsuccessful in married life, who suffers more the bitter consequences of poverty than the wife? But if successful, she has not a dollar to call her own.
quotes.Title: American Activist
quotes.Name: Ernestine Rose

quotes.Text: You get to the point in life where you realize you have to roll up your sleeves, deal with the consequences of what happens, and carry your own weight.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Ernie Isley

quotes.Text: There's no such thing as work-life balance. There are work-life choices, and you make them, and they have consequences.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Jack Welch

quotes.Text: I strive never to forget the real world consequences of my decisions on individuals, businesses and government.
quotes.Title: American Judge
quotes.Name: Sonia Sotomayor

quotes.Text: My lifestyle is a consequence of my wounds. I'm the son of my history.
quotes.Title: Uruguayan Statesman
quotes.Name: Jose Mujica

quotes.Text: Winning is the most important. Everything is consequence of that.
quotes.Title: Brazilian Celebrity
quotes.Name: Ayrton Senna

quotes.Text: We seek the truth and will endure the consequences.
quotes.Title: American Historian
quotes.Name: Charles Seymour
